passage_text: Aluminium carbide, chemical formula Al 4 C 3, is a carbide of aluminium. It has the appearance of pale yellow to brown crystals. It is stable up to 1400 °C.

Examples include calcium carbide (CaC 2), silicon carbide (SiC), tungsten carbide (WC) (often called simply carbide when referring to machine tooling), and cementite (Fe 3 C), each used in key industrial applications. The naming of ionic carbides is not systematic.

There are two structures that can be called carbide. The first is when carbon exists in the -4 oxidation state in combination with a metal. Aluminum carbide, Al4C3, is an example. But aluminum carbide is definitely NOT ionic.

Structure [edit]. Aluminium carbide has an unusual crystal structure that consists of two types of layers. It is based on AlC 4 tetrahedra of two types and thus two types of carbon atoms. One is surrounded by a deformed octahedron of 6 Al atoms at a distance of 217 pm.

Background. Tungsten Carbide is often referred to as a Hard Metal due to it’s very high hardness in relation to other metals. Typically a Tungsten Carbide Hard Metal can have a hardness value of 1600 HV, whereas mild steel would be in the region of 160 HV a factor of 10 lower.

In chemistry, a carbide is a compound composed of carbon and a less electronegative element. Carbides can be generally classified by chemical bonding type as follows: (i) salt-like, (ii) covalent compounds, (iii) interstitial compounds, and (iv) intermediate transition metal carbides.
Aluminium carbide has an unusual crystal structure that consists of two types of layers. It is based on AlC 4 tetrahedra of two types and thus two types of carbon atoms.
